values.name: none
values.prose: No offset path gets created. When offset-path is none, offset-distance and offset-rotate have no effect.

properties.name: offset-distance
properties.percentages: refer to the total path length

properties.name: offset-position
properties.percentages: Refer to the size of containing block
properties.computedValue: The auto keyword or a computed <position>

values.name: auto
values.prose: The initial position is the top-left corner of the box.

values.name: <position>
values.prose: The initial position is the result of using the <position> to position a 0x0 object area within the box’s containing block.

properties.name: offset-anchor
properties.percentages: relative to the width and the height of the element’s reference box
properties.computedValue: the auto keyword or a computed <position>

values.name: auto
values.prose: The anchor point is the same as the point indicated by transform-origin. Specifically, the computed value of transform-origin is resolved as a <position> against the element’s reference box.

values.name: <position>
values.prose: The anchor point is the result of resolving the <position> against the element’s reference box.

properties.name: offset-rotate
properties.computedValue: computed <angle> value, optionally preceded by auto

values.name: auto
values.prose: Indicates that the object is rotated (over time if offset-distance is animated) by the angle of the direction (i.e., directional tangent vector) of the offset path, relative to the positive x-axis. If specified in combination with <angle>, the computed value of <angle> is added to the computed value of auto.

values.name: reverse
values.prose: Indicates that the object is rotated (over time if offset-distance is animated) by the angle of the direction (i.e., directional tangent vector) of the offset path, relative to the positive x-axis, plus 180 degrees. If specified in combination with <angle>, the computed value of <angle> is added to the computed value of reverse.

values.name: <angle>
values.prose: The offset path is a line segment that starts from the initial position and proceeds in the direction defined by the specified <angle>. As with gradient functions, <angle> values are interpreted as bearing angles, with 0deg pointing up and positive angles representing clockwise rotation. This is also the initial direction.

values.name: <ray-size>
values.prose: Specifies the length of the offset path (the distance between the offset-distance: 0% and offset-distance: 100% points) relative to the containing box. If no <ray-size> is specified it defaults to closest-side. Individual keywords are:

values.name: contain
values.prose: The used value of offset-distance is clamped so that the box is entirely contained within the path. If no offset-distance would lead to the box being enclosed by the path, the path size is minimally increased so that such an offset-distance exists. Not clear what this actually means. See Issue 363.

values.name: closest-side
values.prose: The distance from the initial position to whichever side of the containing block is closest.

values.name: closest-corner
values.prose: The distance from the initial position to whichever corner of the containing block is closest.

values.name: farthest-side
values.prose: The distance from the initial position to whichever side of the containing block is farthest.

values.name: farthest-corner
values.prose: The distance from the initial position to whichever corner of the containing block is farthest.

values.name: sides
values.prose: The distance from the initial position to the point where the offset path intersects the containing block’s boundary. If the initial position is on the containing block’s boundary, or outside its bounds entirely, the distance is zero.
